intro: Ipomoea involucrata var. burttii, commonly known as Burtt's morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Convolvulaceae family and is characterized by its trumpet-shaped, showy flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant has heart-shaped leaves and produces tendrils that help it climb and support its growth. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland areas or along stream banks. Its rapid growth and ornamental value make it a popular choice for gardens, though it can be invasive in certain regions.
